column4: Hey guys, I got a question, I need a x64 but I accidently downloaded the x32
Is there any way to update it to x64 instead without having to reinstall it all?
there is no upgrade that I have ever come across, sorry
however, if you keep your /home, then after the re-install your data will still be there
also the 4gb limit.  above 4gb (technically 3.2?) you will need to use PAE for addressing the larger area of memory
so if I have 4gb it's fine?
It feels that ubuntu is really slow though, Windows loads much faster and shit so I thought wrong version might be the prblem
I would almost recommend 32bit over 64 with less than 4gb as the larger addressing space causes you to have less usable memory.  (reference needed)
I got 4gb ram on this laptop so wouldn't it be better to switch it?
define slow.  Anything in particular?
Like loading everything a firefox app takes like 2-4 seconds and this one is completly clean
what about subsequent loads?  It might just be that your disk cache is cold
didn't get what you meant, sorry mind explaining your question, please?

sorry - what I was saying about firefox being slow to load is that the first invocation of a program causes it to be loaded off the disk.  Secondary ivocations of commonly used programs have the advantage of being able to use data that is still in the cache.
but someone else afterwards did say that firefox is slower under Linux, so it's not a fair comparison
oh
I'll try chrominues ors omething liek that to see how it works :)
I'm a die-hard firefox user, so... You can try, but I find once loaded, ff is as quick...
by the way can it be something to do with my computer not meeting the requierments?
bah.  Nearly any computer can meet linux requirements.  Just depends on what gadgets/bells/eye-candy, etc you choose to go along with it :)
I mean this one with untiy thing, maybe that's the main reason it causes lag?

yes.  That is entirely possible.  Microsoft did spend some time with (I think) Vista, to allow basic vs. eye-candy, and I think it chooses for you.  With Unity, you almost need to try and decide to go 2d explicitly if it does not suit your needs
